channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Internet terminals sent by Elon Musk have arrived in Ukraine, according to the country's vice prime minister. The terminals were designed to work with satellites orbiting in space to provide internet access. https://t.co/uPI9IVWicq

Lee Young-ae, a South Korean actress popular in Ukraine, donated $83,500 to help the victims of war there, the Ukrainian ambassador-designate to Seoul​ said​.
Lee said she hoped that “the Ukrainian people will not lose hope and courage.” https://t.co/R0DJVCk9X5

There are traffic gridlocks at Ukraine’s border crossings with Romania, Poland and Moldova as Ukrainian refugees continue to flee their country. About 500,000 people have left Ukraine in recent days, according to the United Nations refugee agency. https://t.co/6UfdpwxsQs https://t.co/2ioGMdVOsJ

An enormous explosion hit central Kharkiv, directly in front of a government building in Ukraine’s second largest city, officials said.
Video of the attack showed a large fireball that appeared to engulf several cars driving through the area. https://t.co/JjIV2DXnKZ https://t.co/oEboRgSgpU

Valery Gergiev, a Russian maestro and prominent supporter of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, was removed from his post as chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic after he refused to denounce Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/fCE9W6B2dG

For many Afghans who fled during the Taliban takeover, the few personal items they could grab are now their only tangible ties to the world they left behind. For Tahera Ahmadi, who sold her jewelry to afford the travel, it was a pin from her eldest sister. https://t.co/uhNHcQiQeL https://t.co/2Xjr3tiXBR

As antiwar protests continued across Russia, the police detained at least 411 people in 13 cities on Monday, an activist group said.
The protests are a remarkable display of defiance in a country where prison terms are sometimes sought for demonstrators. https://t.co/etECbB73Gn https://t.co/zooLbvDvhe

Internet terminals sent by Elon Musk have arrived in Ukraine, according to the country's vice prime minister. The terminals were designed to work with satellites orbiting in space to provide internet access. https://t.co/6DVMHeaH9G

Republican congressional leaders on Monday denounced the actions of two House Republicans — Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia and Representative Paul Gosar of Arizona — who participated in a far-right conference with ties to white supremacy. https://t.co/n8CYa8ztlu

Cryptocurrency investors have donated more than $22 million worth of digital assets to the Ukrainian government and a nonprofit supporting the country’s military, according to data provided by the blockchain tracking firm Elliptic. https://t.co/Zf8Np4nQjN

In Opinion
The idealism of Ukrainians "has turned out to be a powerful weapon," writes Michelle Goldberg. "They’ve shown older democracies what it means to fight for their own putative values, leading to an almost ecstatic global outpouring of support." https://t.co/Wt1zYoIDSX
The U.S. said Monday that it would expel 12 Russian diplomats from Moscow’s UN mission, saying they were actually intelligence operatives who had spied on the United States. https://t.co/JGl93kGyV1
When "wiper" malware appeared to target Ukraine a few hours before Russia's invasion, Microsoft stepped in, throwing itself into the middle of a war. https://t.co/wM51WB5G43

The first talks between Ukraine and Russia aimed at halting the Russian invasion were eclipsed Monday by a deadly Russian rocket assault on Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, that killed at least nine civilians and wounded dozens. https://t.co/42Hm2jl7iS

The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said Monday that he will pursue an investigation into the war in Ukraine, citing a “reasonable basis to believe that both alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed.” https://t.co/9sycoJn4IV
Disney said on Monday that it was “pausing” theatrical releases in Russia, including the Pixar film “Turning Red,” which was scheduled to release there on March 10. https://t.co/75KNP8nY9P
President Volodymyr Zelensky called on Monday for an international tribunal to investigate and punish Russia for its actions in Ukraine, which he described as war crimes. https://t.co/Ra39PmfOJr

About half a million refugees have fled Ukraine since Russia’s invasion began last week, according to the United Nations refugee agency.
About half of them crossed the western border to Poland. Others have gone to Hungary, Moldova, Romania and Slovakia. https://t.co/ktF9ultRmZ https://t.co/mNzTg2PvWr

Senator Richard Durbin has called on the Biden administration to offer Temporary Protected Status to thousands of Ukrainians who are temporarily working or studying in the U.S., allowing them to stay without fear of deportation. https://t.co/YByruo2jaK
Three members of Russia’s rubber-stamp Parliament have criticized their country’s war in Ukraine, a rare episode of dissent from within the Russian establishment. https://t.co/mopHtyoJU9
News Analysis: After miscalculating Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning to an old pattern of firing on cities and mounting sieges. https://t.co/LktaeJhlOX

Putin has tried to control news outlets, social media and the opposition. Yet protests over the war in Ukraine still broke out. @sheeraf and @antontroian discuss Russian public opinion on Tuesday at 12 p.m. ET. DM questions to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/3fGr5m9yvk

Not since the frigid days of the Cold War have so many doors closed on Russia and its people. From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/d4LY4EfHrm

Russian forces inched forward in their campaign to encircle the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, but continued to face "creative and effective" resistance from Ukrainian forces, a senior Pentagon official said on Monday. https://t.co/4x0Lk92uMN

The artists set to represent Russia at the Venice Biennale have pulled out and thousands of others are signing antiwar petitions despite the risks to their careers and the possibility of arrest. https://t.co/c5LjAgtTxk https://t.co/6KgG8g4dG8

Ukrainian officials on Monday accused Russian forces of launching a barrage of rockets on a residential neighborhood in Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv, killing at least nine civilians and injuring dozens of others. https://t.co/WWVPQgdLWT https://t.co/3piPP6leFO

New: Russia-Ukraine peace talks in Belarus have ended, and delegations are returning to capitals for consultations. The end of the discussions coincided with what was reportedly a renewed bombing of Kharkiv as well as explosions in Kyiv. https://t.co/Dwm5g47brm

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has become a hero for many Afghans who felt abandoned after their own president, Ashraf Ghani, fled Afghanistan in August when the Taliban surrounded Kabul. https://t.co/1lYtcILNfB

Dead bodies are piling up on gurneys in hospital hallways as Hong Kong’s health system is overloaded by its biggest coronavirus outbreak of the pandemic. More than 400 people died from Covid-19 last week, the latest official statistics show. https://t.co/7CksISWudx

In the basement shelter of the Okhmadet Children’s Hospital in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, women tended to their sick children as Russian forces closed in on the city. https://t.co/rzssfVY36T https://t.co/mFo2Jw9kOv

Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said Monday it would exit four oil and gas joint ventures with Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, valued at about $3 billion. The decision is a further blow to Russia and its oil industry.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/q6tUKjULGj

In a call with President Vladimir Putin of Russia that lasted an hour and a half, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday urged for an immediate cease-fire and an end to all attacks on civilians and essential infrastructure in Ukraine. https://t.co/x3im17fYbD

New satellite images show Russian ground forces — a convoy stretched out over at least 17 miles — within 30 miles of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. The line of vehicles is so extensive that it was not entirely captured in Monday’s satellite imagery. https://t.co/rty0sb4bJM

In Opinion
“Where once Russia and other autocracies were seen as anti-democratic, they have now become symbols of U.S. conservatism — a mirror for the right-wing worldview,” writes Emily Tamkin, an author and journalist, in a guest essay. https://t.co/73sH579bEU

In a passionate speech on Monday, President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the EU to admit Ukraine immediately: “Our goal is to stand alongside all Europeans and, most importantly, to stand on their level.” https://t.co/xgMrGyltLZ https://t.co/1pRzZTgnuy

Breaking News: FIFA will ban Russia and its teams, ejecting the country from qualifying for the 2022 World Cup only weeks before it was to play for one of Europe’s final places in the tournament. UEFA will join FIFA in issuing and honoring the ban. https://t.co/TVD3uh1oUY https://t.co/cqv9ZvVv7h

Many Ukrainians and Russians, because of their countries’ intertwined history, have relatives from both sides of the border who are now standing on opposite sides of the frontline. It has raised fears that family members will harm each other in battle. https://t.co/GDvqGrkJwb https://t.co/YytITjT0QK

President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the European Union on Monday to grant Ukraine immediate accession to the bloc. “Europeans are aware that our soldiers are fighting for our country and, consequently, for the whole of Europe," he said. https://t.co/ahq2BzchbF https://t.co/Az0OFwgK67

As more people arrive in Lviv, a city in western Ukraine, from the east, the stories they share are growing increasingly dire, our reporter on the ground writes. The train station has filled with people trying to flee the country from Russia's attacks. https://t.co/EIJJgL9QSg https://t.co/wFPKb6pBIJ

Breaking News: Switzerland will freeze Russian assets, including those of President Vladimir Putin, setting aside its long tradition of neutrality. The country is a favorite destination for Russian money.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/gBiE3t0l4m

The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm our ability to adapt, a UN report found. Written by 270 researchers from 67 countries, it is the most detailed look yet at the threats posed by global warming. https://t.co/v6O42BFJRv https://t.co/6RzmiaoObk

Breaking News: The U.S. escalated sanctions with a freeze on Russian central bank assets. The sanctions will limit Russia’s ability to finance its “destabilizing activities,” Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/Xa8bjC71f7

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the EU to grant his country immediate membership of the bloc.
He also had a message for Russian troops in Ukraine: “Abandon your military equipment and leave,” he said. “Save your lives. Leave.” https://t.co/JGBMQM762D https://t.co/yZI2TmjuGw

The pediatrics ward of a children’s hospital in Kyiv was relocated to the hospital’s basement. Women watched over their babies in the bomb shelter as fighting continued in Ukraine. https://t.co/ybG1HTNSS3 https://t.co/QvhVTfLJIs

Ukraine accused Russian forces of launching rockets on a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second largest city, killing dozens of civilians, just as Ukrainian and Russian officials were preparing to meet for talks. https://t.co/G9UCH5H0dv

The Metropolitan Opera will no longer engage with performers or other institutions that have voiced support for President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the company said. https://t.co/3AJKNLUYmN https://t.co/p5dbjJ6cim

As delegations from Ukraine and Russia met for talks in Belarus, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for the EU to grant his country immediate membership. https://t.co/61XoYtrSS1 https://t.co/eI3cIWpd0H

Thousands of people gathered at rallies across the U.S. on Sunday in a show of support for Ukraine. Many waved blue and yellow Ukrainian flags, sang patriotic songs and shouted chants against President Vladimir Putin of Russia. https://t.co/DSnO1Xxdq4 https://t.co/p0DZ8U7xem

Breaking News: The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm our ability to adapt, a UN report found.
The effects of climate change are “much more widespread and much more negative than expected,” one researcher said.https://t.co/qGWhFe6Jev

The UN Human Rights Council brushed aside Russian objections and accepted a request from Ukraine for an urgent debate on Russia’s invasion.
Ukraine is expected to call for a team of human rights experts to monitor and report on abuses and war crimes. https://t.co/VkdUUwsAf8
